title._content: Mary Boyer, First School Teacher, Reading to Students, 1917

description._content: Miss Mary Boyer operated a private school within the buildings of the Grandview system prior to the establishment of the Upper Arlington schools. She was considered one the finest grade school teachers in the state. Miss Boyer was the first schoolteacher in Upper Arlington and taught the village's first, second, and third grades during the 1917-1918 school year, establishing the foundation upon which the Upper Arlington school system was built. She was also the teachers' committee chairman and one of the first four teachers in the resulting school system, which opened in October 1918 with an initial enrollment of fifty-two students. Miss Boyer instructed fourth, fifth, and sixth grade students in the newly created school system. This photograph of Mary Boyer reading to Warren Armstrong and another student was published on page 12 of the Norwester, December 1917, in a feature titled "Education in the Upper Arlington School." Original caption read: "Under home like conditions Miss Boyer is seen here giving personal instruction of a type that would be impossible under crowded city conditions." This image available online at the UA Archives: ua-archives.cdmhost.com/u?/p4036coll10,47 Read Mary Boyer's "Norwester" magazine article at the UA Archives: ua-archives.cdmhost.com/u?/p4036coll9,210 ---------------------------------------- Identifier: hinw02p012i01 Date (yyyy-mm-dd): c. 1917-12 Original Dimensions: 10.2 cm x 16.2 cm Format: Black and White Halftone Photograph Source: Norwester, December 1917, page 12 Original Publisher: Upper Arlington Community (Ohio) Location/s: Upper Arlington (USA, Ohio, Franklin County) Repository: Upper Arlington Historical Society Digital Publisher: UA Archives - Upper Arlington Public Library Credit: UA Archives - Upper Arlington Public Library (Repository: UA Historical Society)
